Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2010 06:03PM MeredithK02 wrote: The waitint until after surgery to know the course of treatment was rough for me, too.  It helped to at least have one active step ahead of me to prepare for (the surgery).  Waiting to hear the surgery date was the worst part for me!  I had a lat flap with tissue expanders put in June 17th.  I've only had one fill, but it was pretty neat.  The doctor has a little magnet gizmo that he puts over the TE to find the port to inject more saline.  The port on mine is at about 12:00 (for some reason, I'd thought it'd be right in the middle!).  The doctor marked where to inject, then took an intimidatingly large needle and inserted it.  A nurse had a bag of saline attached, then measured out the fill and slowly inserted it, all while the doctor held the needle in place.  I could feel the needle on one side, but not the other.  There's some discomfort afterward, at least for me, while your skin and muscle are stretching, but I swear it's not that bad, and I'm a wimp!  :-)
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed and waiting is awful odinsmom dap1961

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2010 10:56PM MeredithK02 wrote: That's great you've gotten the surgery date!   I always seemed to come up with questions on Friday afternoons, right after the doctor's office closes, so I've gotten LOTS of great advice from the ladies here.  I think every single question I had, someone else had asked it before and I could find the answers, or I got super-speedy replies.  Thank goodness for getting my diagnosis during the internet age!
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed and waiting is awful odinsmom dap1961

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2010 12:34AM MeredithK02 wrote: Hi gutsy, That's a rough spot to be.  I didn't have any bad symptoms of breast cancer (my doctor found the lump), so I wasn't in any pain or discomfort until surgery and chemo!  It didn't really feel real until then. One thing I'd caution: I imagined the side effects of things to be a lot worse than they were.  I think that because people post here when they've had a problem, it makes it seem like the problems are more prevalent than they are.  Not that it's going to be an easy road, but that it won't have every obstacle you'd imagine.  Or am I stretching that metaphor too far?  :-) I filled that time waiting for the mastectomy by watching movies and going out with a couple close girlfriends.  They talked about cancer however much I wanted to, but when I was ready to change the subject, we didn't have to wallow in my diagnosis.  That was invaluable.
Posts.Title: Waiting for treatment, feel like I am waiting for the ax to fall gutsy AmyIsStrong

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2009 02:13PM MeredithK02 wrote: Thanks Julie!  My plastic surgeon's nurse said that he advised patients that, if they wanted to use something, he recommended Mederma.  But then he said in-person that it probably only worked because you massaged the scar while applying it, and some post here said that it wasn't found to be clinically effective.  There are so many options out there, it's confusing!  Good luck with your scars--please keep me posted about how everything works out!
Posts.Title: Scar treatment/reduction after mastectomy? MeredithK02 Seabee

Posts.Content: MeredithK02 wrote: Hi everyone, I'm new to this site and pretty new to cancer!  I'm 28, was diagnosed almost a month ago, and underwent a bilateral mastectomy last week.  The surgeons and I had decided that if any lymph nodes tested positive during the surgery, that they would close up without immediate reconstruction.  Since I'll still want the reconstruction eventually, they did a skin-sparing mastectomy.  So things are lumphy and misshapen, but I can't complain!  I wanted to ask if anybody had any recommendations for treating the scars.  I know I've got to wait a little longer before using any silicone sheeting or gels/ointments, but since I'm planning to order it online, I wanted to get everything set in advance.   Diagnosis: 8/17/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIb, Grade 3, 1/8 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Dx 8/17/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/8 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Scar treatment/reduction after mastectomy? MeredithK02 Seabee

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2009 01:57PM MeredithK02 wrote: Thank you so much!  I've been searching online but there are so many options that it's hard to decide what to use!  I'm glad I have a few more weeks to decide!
Posts.Title: Scar treatment/reduction after mastectomy? MeredithK02 Seabee

Posts.Content: MeredithK02 wrote: Hi, I was wondering if anybody can give me advice about my port.  I had it placed 12 days ago and recently the scab came off.  Today it started feeling uncomfortable and the skin around it is distinctly pink and warm.  It hurts when I move my arm on that side in front of my body, and up until now it's been a little painful at the port site, but wasn't painful no matter which direction I moved my arm.  There's no pus or anything that I can see, and I'm not running a temperature.  Has anyone else with a port experienced this?    I'm going in Friday for my next chemo treatment, so I'm certainly planning to ask about it then, but I'd love to hear from some of you in the meantime.   Diagnosis: 8/17/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIb, Grade 3, 1/8 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Dx 8/17/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/8 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Port pain--when is it a problem? MeredithK02 MeredithK02

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2009 08:43AM MeredithK02 wrote: Thanks, Nancy and Chelee, the warmness was concerning me, too.  I'm going to call my oncologist's office when they open this morning and go in to have it checked out.   I know most posters here probably aren't doctors, but sometimes it can be helpful to hear from so many people who've been through the same thing! Meredith
Posts.Title: Port pain--when is it a problem? MeredithK02 MeredithK02

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2009 07:26PM MeredithK02 wrote: Just a quick update--I went to the doctor, who thought it looked like a staph infection, so I've started antibiotics.  Meredith
